page.description: Imports a fixed length ascii file into an existing table. Ascii file must match the structure of the table. If ascii file has fieldnames, set skip_lines to 1
page.syntax: Record_Count as C = Table.Import_Ascii_Table(C ascii_filename [,N skip_lines [,L silent ]])

argument.name: Record_Count
argument.description: The number of records processed, imported and not imported (because they violated a field rule in the target table). The format of the result string is:

argument.name: ascii_filename
argument.description: The name of the file to import.

argument.name: skip_lines
argument.description: Optional. Default = 0. Indicates how many rows to skip in the file being imported. If the file that you are importing has field names in row 1, then you would set Skip_Lines to 1.

item.name: .T. = Alpha Anywhere does not display a confirmation message.
.F. = Alpha Anywhere does display a confirmation message after the data is imported.

page.discussion: The .IMPORT_ASCII_TABLE() method imports a CR-LF delimited ASCII file directly into a table. The ASCII data must exactly mach the format of the table. For example, assume that the table that you want to import data into has this structure:

section.description: The ASCII file must have "Customer" data starting in column 1, "City" data starting in column 21, and "State" data starting in column 36.

section.title: Example
section.description: The following Xbasic snippet shows how this method can be used to import data contained in a file called "c:\tabledata.txt" into a table called "customers":
section.example: Dim tbl as P Tbl = table.open("customers") Tbl.Import_Ascii_Table("c:\tabledata.txt",1,.f.) Tbl.close()
